title: Cats. 14–15  Small Crouching Nude without an Arm, 1908 • Standing Female Nude, Twisting toward Her Back, 1908
publication_title: Matisse Paintings, Works on Paper, Sculpture, and Textiles at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Small Crouching Nude without an Arm  
Paris, 1908, cast by October 1909  
Bronze; edition 2/10; height: 23.5 cm (9 1/4 in.)  
Signed and numbered: HM 2/10 (proper left thigh)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Emily Crane Chadbourne, 1932.1145

Standing Female Nude, Twisting toward Her Back  
Paris, c. 1908  
Graphite, with stumping, on tan wove paper, laid down on cream wove paper, laid down on ivory wove paper; primary support: 30.9 × 23.6 cm (12 1/8 × 9 1/2 in.); secondary support: 32.9 × 25.7 cm (12 7/8 × 10 in.); tertiary support: 37.9 × 30.5 cm (15 × 12 in.)  
Signed: Henri Matisse (in graphite, lower right)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Alfred Stieglitz Collection, 1949.894

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">As Henri Matisse searched his painted forms for their truest expression, he often turned to other media. He undertook these other works, however, not to explore alternatives for the composition but to refine and solidify the forms he had already identified. Made during the process of painting, these related works served the artist as exercises to confirm and clarify his means. Such is the case with Bathers with a Turtle (Dec. 1907–1908; fig. 14–15.1), which generated numerous sculptures and drawings, including the Art Institute’s Small Crouching Nude without an Arm and Standing Female Nude, Twisting toward Her Back.

Late in 1907, Matisse began the large-scale Bathers with a Turtle, a work that would mark a fresh direction in which the artist drew upon his practice of repeating motifs in numerous paintings and sculptures, and forged a new approach predicated on an exceptional degree of reworking, now on the same canvas. Matisse first painted the group seen in Bathers with a Turtle in the smaller Three Bathers (fig. 14–15.2), initially titled Le bain, which he made before a trip to Italy in the summer of 1907. He reprised and synthesized it for Le luxe (I) (summer 1907; fig. 14–15.3) and Le luxe (II) (summer–fall 1907; fig. 14–15.4), produced after his return. In these works, the artist employed the same three figures seen in Bathers with Turtle, repeating their standing, crouching, and sitting (or striding) poses with small variations even as he moved the overall composition toward greater simplification.

Matisse’s repetitive practice served his goal of paring his forms down to their purest, most meaningful state, or what he called their “truer, more essential character.” This way of working extended beyond his own creations; he also consistently revisited poses and subjects that he gleaned from mass-produced photographs of models in publications such as L’études académique and Mes modeles as well as from paintings by a diverse range of artists, including, Paul Cézanne, Giorgione, Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres, Pierre Puvis de Chavannes, and Titian. By repeatedly reusing these artistic resources, Matisse sought to mine—or rather, drain—forms of specific meaning to achieve a greater, more universal vocabulary of expression. “When I see the Giotto frescoes at Padua,” he wrote in “Notes d’un peintre” about the great work he had seen in the summer of 1907, “I do not trouble myself to recognize which scene of the life of Christ I have before me, but I immediately understand the feeling that emerges from it, for it is in the lines, the composition, the color. The title will only serve to confirm my impression.”

Small Crouching Nude without an Arm, which was acquired by the Chicago collector Emily Crane Chadbourne in October 1909, belongs to a series of small-scale sculptures made early in the preceding year and in which Matisse reworked the motif to progressively eliminate more detail. He was inspired to make the first in the group, Small Crouching Nude with Arms (1908; fig. 14–15.5), by a photograph from Amédée Vignola’s nude photographic revue, L’études académique, in which a female model sits on one leg while bending tightly over the other, one arm bent and the other firmly planted on the ground in a “gesture of despondency.” Matisse modeled the clay form with his hands, paying special attention to the curve of the back and spine. Soon after, while attempting to show the sculpture to his patron Sarah Stein, who was also a student at his newly founded art school, Matisse broke its outstretched arm. Though he wanted to destroy it, Stein dissuaded him and instead he reworked the figure, obliterating detail as he solidified the form.

For this work, Matisse removed the base, smoothed the features, and filled once-empty spaces (see, for instance, the gaps below the chin and below the figure’s right leg); his efforts made the figure more hunched and the pose more compressed. The result was Small Crouching Nude without an Arm, cast in bronze. Soon Matisse chose to revise the figure again, this time editing out the head, arms, and parts of the legs, focusing exclusively on the curving back so that the resulting egg-like form is completely closed (1908; fig. 14–15.6). Each time Matisse reworked these handheld forms he reinforced the strong, curving, compact shape of the back, which in turn informed his painting. Examination of Bathers with a Turtle reveals repeated reworking and readjustment of the poses of the figures: the crouching figure on the left, for example, was first painted with her head in profile and lower than it is at present. Her right arm, now reaching toward the turtle, was once closer to her torso, while her right knee extended beyond her arm, much like the right arm and leg in Small Crouching Nude with Arms. Matisse enlarged and altered the woman’s curved back several times, reflecting the same evolution depicted in his three sculpted figures.

Standing Female Nude, Twisting toward Her Back relates to Matisse’s work on the central figure of Bathers with a Turtle, which started in profile, shifted to a frontal view, and then finally arrived at the current orientation. Examination with infrared reflectography (fig. 14–15.7) reveals that while Matisse kept the left arm of the painted figure in more or less the same position, he repeatedly readjusted the right one as he made the posture more erect. The artist made similar changes in the drawing, leaving the earlier arm and leg positions visible. Choosing soft graphite, he was able to work the medium to produce broad lines that function as both shadow and volume, as well as reinforcement of the physical nature of his own experimentation. Matisse’s many changes to the arms and back were not erased but enhanced by his use of the stump, or estompe, and incorporated into the final image. Indeed, what might have traditionally been called pentimenti in an earlier work can only be seen here as an integral part of the finished composition. As means of proof of the importance of such marks, Matisse selected Standing Female Nude, Twisting toward Her Back for his second exhibition at Alfred Stieglitz’s 291 Gallery, New York, which ran from February 23 to March 8, 1910. Given the importance of this event to the artist’s continued patronage and career, we should take special note of the “finish” Matisse wanted to present.

In the context of Matisse’s various explorations of ways of reworking repeated motifs, Bathers with a Turtle and its related works are striking examples of his incorporation of visible change to generate and determine a composition’s final form. Matisse’s embrace of the concept of evolution in his working process would become an increasingly significant aspect of his artistic experimentation in the second decade of the twentieth century.  
Stephanie D’Alessandro

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">The work has had the following titles:

1951: Figure (Alfred H. Barr, Jr., “Appendix F: Works by Matisse in the Public Museums of English-Speaking Countries,” in Matisse: His Art and His Public [Museum of Modern Art, New York, 1951], p. 558.)

1996: Petit nu accroupi avec un bras (Rémi Labrusse, “Esthétique decorative et experience critique: Matisse, Byzance et la notion d’Orient,” vol. 1 [Ph.D. diss., Université de Paris I, Panthéon-Sorbonne, 1996], p. 155 n. 32.)

1997: Petit Nu accroupi avec un bras/Petit Nu accroupi sans bras droit/Petit Nu accroupi, bras droit cassé/Small Crouching Nude without an Arm (Claude Duthuit and Wanda de Guébriant, Henri Matisse: Catalogue raisonné de l’oeuvre sculpté [C. Duthuit, 1997], p. 100, cat. 38.)

Duthuit and de Guébriant, Henri Matisse, p. 100, cat. 38.

Claude Duthuit and Wanda de Guébriant’s catalogue raisonné gives the date cast as “before 1936”; Duthuit and de Guébriant, Henri Matisse, p. 100, cat. 38, no. 2. However, the sculpture was acquired by Emily Crane Chadbourne in early October 1909 and therefore must have been cast by that date; see Robert Gathorne-Hardy, ed., Ottoline: The Early Memoirs of Lady Ottoline Morrell (Faber & Faber, 1963), pp. 183, 186, 189.

The work has had the following titles:

Apr. 1920: Drawing No. 2 (Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, Catalogue of an Exhibition of Paintings and Drawings by Representative Modern Artists, exh. cat. [Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, 1920], p. 16, cat. 154.)

Oct. 1937: Drawing No. 2 (American Place, Beginnings and Landmarks: “291” 1905–1917, exh. cat. [American Place, 1937], cat. 35.)

July 1944: Nude Standing (Philadelphia Museum of Art, History of an American, Alfred Stieglitz: “291” and After, exh. cat. [Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1944], p. 12, cat. 55.)

Jan. 1966: Standing Nude/Nu debout (UCLA Arts Council and UCLA Art Galleries, Henri Matisse, exh. cat. [University of California Press, 1966], p. 197, cat. 149.)

May 1975: Femme nue debout, de face, la corps tourné vers la gauche (Isabelle Monod-Fontaine and Dominique Fourcade, “Dessins,” in Musée National d’Art Moderne, Henri Matisse: dessins et sculpture, exh. cat. [Centre Georges Pompidou, 1975], p. 81, cat. 33.)

Sept. 1975: Femme nue debout, de face, le corps tourné vers la gauche and Staand naakt inn vooraanzicht, naar links gekeerd (Isabelle Monod-Fontaine and Dominique Fourcade, “Dessins/Tekeningen,” in Société des Expositions du Palais des Beaux-Arts de Bruxelles, Henri Matisse: Dessins et sculpture/Tekeningen en sculpturen, exh. cat. [Société des Expositions du Palais des Beaux-Arts de Bruxelles, 1975], cat. 31.)

1993: Femme nue debout (Centre Georges Pompidou, Henri Matisse, 1904–1917, exh. cat. [Centre Georges Pompidou, 1993], p. 93 [ill.].)

The work has been assigned various dates:

Oct. 1937: 1910 (American Place, Beginnings and Landmarks, cat. 35.)

July 1944: 1910 (Philadelphia Museum of Art, History of an American, p. 12, cat. 55.)

Jan. 1966: 1908 (UCLA Arts Council and UCLA Art Galleries, Henri Matisse, p. 197, cat. 149.)

May 1975: 1906 (?) 1908 (?) (Monod-Fontaine and Fourcade, “Dessins,” p. 81, cat. 33.)

Sept. 1975: 1906 (?) 1908 (?) (Monod-Fontaine and Fourcade, “Dessins/Tekeningen,” cat. 31.)

1993: 1910 (Centre Georges Pompidou, Henri Matisse, 1904–1917, p. 93.)

Mar. 2010: 1908 (Stephanie D’Alessandro and John Elderfield, Matisse: Radical Invention, 1913–1917, exh. cat. [Art Institute of Chicago/Museum of Modern Art, New York/Yale University Press, 2010], p. 71, cat. 3m.)

Matisse’s work on the canvas would continue into the first months of 1908. See Stephanie D’Alessandro, “Bathers with a Turtle,” in D’Alessandro and Elderfield, Matisse, pp. 66–71; portions of this essay are adapted from the text.

See Henri Matisse to Félix Fénéon, July 8, 1907, Archives Henri Matisse, Paris. According to Wanda de Guébriant, Archives Henri Matisse, the artist wrote on the verso of a photograph of Three Bathers: “Composition: Étude pour la peinture ‘Les Femmes à la tortue.’” See Yve-Alain Bois, “Matisse’s Bathers with a Turtle, ”Saint Louis Art Museum Bulletin 22, no. 3 (Fall 1998): p. 19 n. 1. Henri and Amélie Matisse were in Florence by July 18, where they visited Sandro Botticelli’s Birth of Venus (1482–85) and Titian’s Portrait of a Woman (1510–12); their tour also included Siena, Ravenna, Padua, and Venice. They returned to Collioure on August 14. For more on Matisse’s time in Italy, see Rémi Labrusse and Jacqueline Munck, Matisse-Derain: La verité du fauvisme (Hazan, 2005), pp. 291–92.

For information on the continuation of idyllic painting, see Margaret Werth, The Joy of Life: The Idyllic in French Art, circa 1900 (University of California Press, 2002), esp. pp. 223–31. The women in Bathers with a Turtle, however, are all but divorced from any narrative—gone is the recognizable landscape of earth, sea, and sky of the earlier paintings as well as the bouquets, clouds, drapery, hills, sailboats, and towels that suggested a leisure or vaguely Golden Age subject. Their gestures do not communicate a specific purpose, and the turtle itself is an enigmatic, unsettling element that calls attention to the nearby crouching bather, but for no clear reason. The figures are stripped and starkly bared against three plain horizontal bands, firmly separated from the traditional pastoral context in which it would have been permissible to view them.

Henri Matisse, “Notes d’un peintre,” La grande revue 2, no. 24 (Dec. 25, 1908), p. 736.

For more on Matisse’s photographic sources, see Isabelle Monod-Fontaine, The Sculpture of Henri Matisse, exh. cat., trans. David Macey (Thames & Hudson/Arts Council of Great Britain, 1984); and Ellen McBreen, Matisse’s Sculpture: The Pinup and the Primitive (Yale University Press, 2014). Among the many contemporary paintings he used for inspiration, one of the most relevant is Cézanne’s Large Bathers (1898–1905; Philadelphia Museum of Art), which was shown in a special exhibition at the 1907 Salon d’Automne where Matisse also exhibited works, including Le luxe (I) (summer 1907; fig. 3). For more about Cézanne’s impact on Matisse, see Yve-Alain Bois, “Cézanne and Matisse: From Apprenticeship to Creative Misreading,” in Cézanne and Beyond, exh. cat., ed. Joseph J. Rishel and Katherine Sachs (Philadelphia Museum of Art, 2009), pp. 103–20. In the summer of 1907, Matisse added the work of artists he studied while visiting Italy to his list of sources: most significant for Bathers with a Turtle were Duccio’s Maestà (1308–11; Museo dell’Opera del Duomo, Siena), the frescoes of Giotto’s Scrovegni Chapel (1303–06) in Padua, those of Piero della Francesca in the Basilica di San Francesco (c. 1466) in Arezzo, and Andrea del Castagno’s in Sant’Apollonia (c. 1447–49) in Florence.

Matisse, “Notes d’un peintre,” p. 741.

Also related to this group is the somewhat larger bronze sculpture Seated Figure, Right Hand on Ground (1908; Duthuit 42). According to Lady Ottoline Morrell, an acquaintance of Emily Crane Chadbourne who accompanied her to visit Matisse for the first time: “Miss Chadbourne and I sat on a chair on which a portfolio of his drawings were propped. He stood turning them over for us to see and choose one to buy. She appeared to take no interest, indeed hardly looked at the drawings, but from time to time picked off little bits of dust and fluff from her black skirt. She gave no heed to his remarks and explanations. When he had gone through the drawings she silently got up, without any comment, wandered round the room, took up a small bronze figure in her white-gloved hand and said she would like to buy it and walked out to her motor, Matisse bowing to her very graciously on seeing his bronze figure depart with her.” See Gathorne-Hardy, Ottoline, p. 189. Chadbourne would go on to acquire several works by the artist in the coming years (see cat. 16, cat. 17, and cat. 43).

Matisse owned this volume, which is currently housed in the Archives Henri Matisse, Paris; for more on this particular photograph, see McBreen, Matisse’s Sculpture.

According to Museum of Modern Art, Four Americans in Paris: The Collection of Gertrude Stein and Her Family (Museum of Modern Art, New York, 1970), p. 162, Sarah Stein told Mr. and Mrs. Lionel Steinberg, that Matisse had picked her up at their school in Paris for a walk in the rain and drew Small Crouching Nude with Arms from his raincoat pocket, breaking off the arm. He was greatly disturbed and wanted to destroy it, but she persuaded him not to, and he cast it without the arm.

Pentimenti are defined as the visible evidence of an alteration to a painting or drawing that traditionally suggest a change of mind on the part of an artist. The term can also refer to such effects when they do not signify a replacement but rather are part of alterations the artist made to the composition as he worked. In the context of Matisse’s various explorations with ways of reworking and repeating motifs and compositions, the marks in Bathers with a Turtle indicate a mindful practice of incorporating change throughout a composition into the final form of a painting.

</section><section id="figures">Cats. 14–15 Left: Small Crouching Nude without an Arm, 1908 (cat. 14). Right: Standing Female Nude, Twisting toward Her Back, 1908 (cat. 15).

fig. 14–15.1 Henri Matisse (French, 1869–1954). Bathers with a Turtle, Dec. 1907–08. Oil on canvas; 179.1 × 220.3 cm (70 1/2 × 87 3/4 in.). Saint Louis Art Museum, gift of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Pulitzer Jr., 24:1964.

fig. 14–15.2 Henri Matisse (French, 1869–1954). Three Bathers, summer 1907. Oil on canvas; 60.3 × 73 cm (23 3/4 × 28 3/4 in.). Minneapolis Institute of Art, bequest of Putnam Dana McMillan, 61.36.14.

fig. 14–15.3 Henri Matisse (French, 1869–1954). Le luxe (I), summer 1907. Oil on canvas; 210 × 138 cm (82 5/8 × 41 3/8 in.). Musée National d’Art Moderne, Centre de Création Industrielle, Centre Pompidou, Paris, AM 2586 P.

fig. 14–15.4 Henri Matisse (French, 1869–1954). Le luxe (II), summer–fall 1907. Distemper on canvas; 209.5 × 138 cm (82 1/2 × 54 3/8 in.). Statens Museum for Kunst, Copenhagen, KMSr76.

fig. 14–15.5 Henri Matisse (French, 1869–1954). Small Crouching Nude with Arms, profile view, 1908. Bronze; ed. 2/10; h. 14.4 cm (5 1/2 in.). Private collection.

fig. 14–15.6 Henri Matisse (French, 1869–1954). Small Crouching Torso, side view, 1908. Bronze; ed. 7/10; h. 7.8 cm (3 1/16 in.). Musée Matisse, Nice.

fig. 14–15.7 Infrared reflectogram of Matisse’s Bathers with a Turtle, Dec. 1907–1908. Saint Louis Art Museum, gift of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Pulitzer Jr., 24:1964.

</section>
